what: Calculate and compare two correlations — calculate.and.compare.correlations

Calculate and compare two correlations — calculate.and.compare.correlations
text: x1 Vector x-values correlation 1 x2 Vector x-values correlation 2 y1 Vector y-values correlation 1 y2 Vector y-values correlation 2 method correlation method used? Currently supports Spearman's rho

title: Calculate and compare two correlations — calculate.and.compare.correlations
text: return value

title: Calculate and compare two correlations — calculate.and.compare.correlations
text: Paul C. Boutros

title: Calculate and compare two correlations — calculate.and.compare.correlations
text: worry use length(x1) length(x2) code. really need determining number jointly non-NA entries (since set use = 'pairwise.complete.obs'). think something like length( x1[ !.na(x1&y1) ] );

title: Calculate and compare two correlations — calculate.and.compare.correlations

what: Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
title: Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
text: Calculates concordance correlation coefficient derived Lin set matched observations multiple classes.

title: Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
text: data.mat matrix numeric data, columns representing classes row representing matched observations

title: Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
text: function calculates Lin concordance correlation coefficient set matched observations number observers. Roughly speaking, metric measures orthogonal distance data y=x line. information Lin's methods, see 'concordance correlation coefficient evaluate reproducability', Biometrics 1989, 45:1, pp. 255-68 (Section 7) 'note concordance correlation coefficient', Biometrics 2000, 56:1, pp. 324-325 (correction formula given former).

title: Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
text: Returns single value interval [-1,1] representing degree classes concordance one another (interpreted Pearson Spearman correlation coefficient).

title: Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
text: Michal Grzadkowski

title: Calculate Lin's concordance correlation coefficient — calculate.concordance.coefficient
code: # a matrix with four classes of 100 random observations each data.matrix1 <- matrix(       runif(400),       ncol = 4       ); calculate.concordance.coefficient(data.matrix1); #> [1] 0.01048962  # a matrix with four classes of 100 similar observations each base.data <- sample(     x = 0:1000,     size = 100,     replace = TRUE     ); data.matrix2 <- matrix(       c(         base.data,         base.data + runif(100),         base.data + runif(100),         base.data + runif(100)         ),       ncol = 4       ); calculate.concordance.coefficient(data.matrix2); #> [1] 0.9999989

title: Calculate overlap and p-value — calculate.overlap.and.pvalue
text: Calculate actual overlap corresponding p-value using hypergeometric distribution well expected overlap.

title: Calculate overlap and p-value — calculate.overlap.and.pvalue
code: calculate.overlap.and.pvalue(list1, list2, total.size, lower.tail = TRUE, adjust = FALSE);

title: Calculate overlap and p-value — calculate.overlap.and.pvalue
text: list1 Vector representing query list list2 Vector representing reference list compared total.size Numerical value representing total size reference sample pool lower.tail logical calculating p-value; TRUE (default), probability P[X <= x], otherwise, P[X > x] unless adjust = TRUE.  See phyper adjust logical calculations lower.tail = FALSE; FALSE (default), P[X > x], otherwise, P[X >= x]

title: Calculate overlap and p-value — calculate.overlap.and.pvalue
text: Calculations based using list2 basis comparison list1 list2 come sample pool, matter list1 list2 designated. careful interpreting results lower.tail = FALSE probability P[X > x] P[X >= x].

title: Calculate overlap and p-value — calculate.overlap.and.pvalue
text: Returns three-element vector containing actual overlap, expected overlap p-value

title: Calculate overlap and p-value — calculate.overlap.and.pvalue
text: Paul C. Boutros Denise Mak

title: Calculate overlap and p-value — calculate.overlap.and.pvalue
code: # SNP array example 1 # Total number of SNPs on array is 2000 # Identified 56 special SNPs in group1 # Identified 78 special SNPs in group2 # 10 interesting SNPs are common to both groups # Question: Is 10 greater or less than what we would expect?  list1 <- paste("SNP", 1:56); list2 <- paste("SNP", 47:124); total.size <- 2000;  # Expected overlap is 2.2  # SNP array example 2 # Total number of SNPs on array is 2000 # 500 SNPs on array found on chromosome 1  # Identified 41 special SNPs # 5 interesting SNPs found on chromosome 1 # Question: Is 5 over or under-represented on chromosome 1 as compared to # the proportion of chromosome 1 SNPs on the array?  list1 <- paste("SNP", 1:41); list2 <- paste("SNP", 37:536); total.size <- 2000;  # Expected overlap is 10.3  # Calculate if over-represented calculate.overlap.and.pvalue(   list1 = list1,    list2 = list2,   total.size = total.size,   lower.tail = FALSE,   adjust = TRUE   ); #> Warning: Calculating P[X >= x] #> [1]  5.0000000 10.2500000  0.9874854 # Note: calculation is for P[X > x]  # Calculate if under-represented calculate.overlap.and.pvalue(   list1 = list1,    list2 = list2,   total.size = total.size,   lower.tail = TRUE,   adjust = FALSE   ); #> [1]  5.00000000 10.25000000  0.03507362 # Note: calculation is for P[X <= x]

Compares two Correlations — compare.correlations
text: Tests two correlation coefficients (given sample-sizes) determine statistically similar.

title: Compares two Correlations — compare.correlations
Compares two Correlations — compare.correlations
text: corr1 First Spearman's Rho (raw) corr2 Second Spearman's Rho (raw) n1 First sample-size n2 Second sample-size method correlation method used? Currently supports Spearman's rho

title: Compares two Correlations — compare.correlations
text: Returns vector length nine containing: corr1, corr2, sd1, sd2, delta.corr, pooled SD, p-value, n1, n2

title: Compares two Correlations — compare.correlations
text: Spearman's rho use formulae : Fieller et al. "Tests Rank Correlation Coefficients. ," Biometrica, Vol. 44, . 3/4 (Dec. 1957)

title: Compares two Correlations — compare.correlations
text: Mehrdad Shamsi

title: Compares two Correlations — compare.correlations
code: # this small differential correlation is actually borderline significant (p = 0.10)  compare.correlations(   corr1 = 0.15,   corr2 = -0.15,   n1 = 55,   n2 = 80,   method = 'spearman'   ); #> [1]  0.15000000 -0.15000000  0.02038462  0.01376623 -0.30228087  0.18479948 #> [7]  0.10189745 55.00000000 80.00000000

what: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
title: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
text: Returns values constructing confidence bands one-sample qq plot

title: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
code: create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval(x, distribution = qnorm, conf = 0.95,     conf.method = "both", reference.line.method = "quartiles");

title: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
text: x numeric vector distribution quantile function takes vector probabilities argument produces corresponding quantiles theoretical distribution, defaults "qnorm", normal distribution. conf Confidence level, default 0.95 conf.method Methods used draw confidence bands must one "simultaneous", "pointwise", ""(default). reference.line.method Methods used draw reference line must one "quartiles"(default), "diagonal", "robust".

title: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
text: Returns values creating upper lower bands qq plot.

title: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
text: Note function works single panel qq plot, grouped data multi-qq plot.

title: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
text: Ying Wu

title: Create the confidence bands for a one-sample qq plot — create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval
code: tmp.x <- rnorm(100);  tmp.confidence.interval <- create.qqplot.fit.confidence.interval(tmp.x);  qqnorm(tmp.x); qqline(tmp.x); lines(tmp.confidence.interval$z, tmp.confidence.interval$upper.pw, lty = 2, col = "brown"); lines(tmp.confidence.interval$z, tmp.confidence.interval$lower.pw, lty = 2, col = "brown"); lines(tmp.confidence.interval$z[tmp.confidence.interval$u],      tmp.confidence.interval$upper.sim, lty = 2, col = "blue"); lines(tmp.confidence.interval$z[tmp.confidence.interval$l],      tmp.confidence.interval$lower.sim, lty = 2, col = "blue");  legend(1, -1.5, c("simultaneous", "pointwise"), col = c("blue", "brown"), lty = 2, bty = "n");

title: Coefficient of Biomodality — get.coefficient.of.bimodality
text: Calculates coefficient bimodality vector, defined (1+skewness^2)/(kurtosis+3). normal distributions, value close 0.16667; uniform distributions, close 0.5555; bimodal distributions, coefficient close 1.

code: ttest.analysis(values = c(rnorm(n=50, mean=0), rnorm(n=50, mean=10)),      groups = factor(c(rep('A', times=50), rep('B', times=50)))); #>   statistical.method alternative.hypothesis       pvalue group.1 group.2 #> 1              ttest              two.sided 5.224192e-72       A       B #>   mean.group.1 mean.group.2 #> 1     -0.11386      10.0614

title: Weighted AIC — weighted.AIC
text: Denise Mak

title: Weighted AIC — weighted.AIC
code: set.seed(123456789);  # creating sample non-linear data temp <- data.frame(x = 1:100); temp$y <- temp$x^2-rnorm(100, 0, 500);  # fitting with different models # linear model fit1 <- lm(y~x, data = temp); # quadratic model fit2 <- lm(y~x + I(x^2), data = temp); # logistic model fit3 <- nls(y~SSlogis(x, Asym, xmid, scal), data = temp);  if (FALSE) { # Example to visualize different fits plot(temp); lines(temp$x, predict(fit1), col = "blue") lines(temp$x, predict(fit2), col = "red") lines(temp$x, predict(fit3), col = "green") }  # calculate AIC values (see stats::AIC for more information) x <- AIC(fit1, fit2, fit3);  # quadratic model has the highest probability and the best fit weighted.AIC(x$AIC); #> [1] 3.008714e-27 9.819502e-01 1.804976e-02
